DOC.HEAD: Former Unisys Security Guard Charged With Manipulating Payroll
DOC.TEXT: A former head of security for Unisys Corp. was charged Friday with manipulating payroll records, leading the company to overcharge the federal government $70,732. Joseph Schulz, 60, of Richboro, was charged with causing false statements to be made to the Department of Defense from September 1986 to September 1988. During that time, Schulz was employed as a guard captain for National Guardian Security Services, which provided security to Unisys on government contract work, according to U.S. Attorney Michael Baylson. Schulz was responsible for scheduling and supervising guards at Unisys. According to the charges, Schulz manipulated payroll records to show that more security guards were on duty than actually worked, resulting in Unisys sending false invoices to the Defense Department for payment. If convicted, Schulz faces a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine, according to Baylson. No one answered at a phone listed in Schulz's name to comment on the charge Friday night.
